[Scene adjusted: We return to the weeks following the summer muster and the extraordinary news from Granada.]


Diego de Daza stands before you in the council chamber, the afternoon light slanting through tall windows. He has brought a leather satchel stuffed with reports from across the realm—three years' worth of correspondence with masters, guild officials, and Crown agents.


"Your Majesty asks about the economic programs," Diego begins, setting out his notes with the methodical precision that has become his hallmark. "We are now entering the fourth year since the first initiatives were launched in 1434, and the third year for those begun in 1435. Allow me to summarize by industry."


He clears his throat.


"Paper mills—Segovia and Toledo both remain operational. Wilhelm Hartmann and Marco da Pescia continue their work. The original projections suggested five thousand florins revenue by this year, with first apprentices contributing. We have ten Castilians who began training in 1435—they should now be approaching journeyman status.


"The wool breeding program—this year marks the first improved wool clip from our crossbred sheep. The lambs born in 1437 from English rams and Castilian ewes are now being sheared for the first time. The question is whether the improvement is measurable.


"Textiles—the Ghent consortium under Gillis de Coninck has been operating for three years. Original projections suggested thirty-five hundred florins revenue by now, with Castilian apprentices beginning to contribute meaningfully.


"Arms and armor—Heinrich Steinmann's workshop in Bilbao should be at five to six hundred soldier's kits per year if the projections held. Four years of operation.


"Glass—Alessandro Barbarigo remains in Burgos. His operation was always the slowest to develop given the secrecy required. Projected fifteen hundred florins revenue by this year.


"The traditional industries—leather in Córdoba, silk in Granada, fishing in Seville—all have had four years to develop from our initial investments.


"And ceramics..." Diego pauses. "Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar would now be seventy-seven years old, if he still lives. We have had no word from Málaga in some time."


He looks up from his notes.


"Your Majesty, I can tell you what the projections said. But projections are not reality. Foreign masters grow homesick, fall ill, or quarrel with apprentices. Apprentices prove clumsy or clever beyond expectation. Guilds resist or cooperate. Weather affects wool and leather. Markets shift."

Paper Mills — Segovia & Toledo


"The paper mills have exceeded every expectation," Diego begins, and there's a note of genuine satisfaction in his voice. "Wilhelm Hartmann in Segovia now produces six hundred reams annually—a hundred more than projected. The quality remains consistent, and he has begun experimenting with larger sheets for maps and architectural drawings."


He sets down a sheet of paper, crisp and cream-colored, bearing a watermark of the Castilian castle.


"Marco da Pescia in Toledo has done something remarkable. His fine paper has attracted attention beyond our borders. The papal chancery—the papal chancery, Your Majesty—has placed an order for five hundred sheets of his finest stock. They say it rivals anything produced in Italy."


Diego allows himself a small smile. "Combined revenue this year will approach seven thousand florins. We projected five thousand."


"More importantly, of the ten apprentices who began in 1435, eight have advanced to journeyman status. Two have proven exceptional—one in Segovia, one in Toledo. Hartmann says the Segovian boy, Martín de Ávila, has 'the hands of a born papermaker.' Within two years, we could open a third mill staffed entirely by Castilians trained in both German and Italian methods."



Wool Breeding Program — Segovia


"This year marks our first true test," Diego continues, his tone more measured. "The crossbred lambs born in 1437 were sheared this spring. I have here..."


He produces a small cloth bag and withdraws two samples of raw wool—one darker, coarser; one lighter and noticeably finer.


"The darker is standard Castilian merino. Good wool, as it has always been. The lighter is from our first crossbred generation—English Ryeland rams bred to Castilian ewes."


He hands you the samples. The difference is evident even to an untrained hand—the crossbred wool is softer, with a longer staple.


"The Segovia woolmen are... cautiously excited. They say the improvement is measurable but not yet dramatic. Perhaps fifteen to twenty percent finer than baseline merino. The true test comes with the second generation—lambs born this spring from crossbred ewes bred back to English rams. Those sheep will be sheared in 1440."


Diego pauses. "We lost three more rams to illness last winter, but fourteen of the original sixteen English bloodlines survive. The breeding master believes we are on pace to match English wool quality by 1445, perhaps sooner if the second generation exceeds expectations."



Textile Workshop — Segovia (Ghent Consortium)


"Gillis de Coninck and his partners have done everything we asked and more," Diego reports. "The workshop now produces finished broadcloths that Flemish merchants mistake for Ghent work—and I mean that literally. A Bruges factor tried to buy their entire stock last year, assuming it was smuggled Flemish goods."


He produces a swatch of deep crimson wool cloth, the color rich and even.


"Mathijs Coppens has achieved something with his dyes that even he did not expect. The crimson you see here holds its color through twenty washings. Coppens claims he has improved upon techniques he learned in Ghent by adapting to local mordants. 'Castilian water,' he says, 'is better for reds than Flemish water.' I do not pretend to understand, but the results speak."


"Revenue to the masters this year approaches five thousand florins—we projected thirty-five hundred. They have trained fourteen Castilian apprentices, two of whom are nearly ready to establish their own looms. And..." Diego hesitates, as if uncertain whether to share the next detail.


"The consortium has asked permission to recruit their families from Ghent. Wives, children, aging parents. They wish to make Castile their permanent home. I take this as a sign they see their future here, not as exiles but as founders of something lasting."



Arms & Armor Workshop — Bilbao


"Heinrich Steinmann's operation in Bilbao has matured into something formidable," Diego says. "This year they produced six hundred and forty complete soldier's kits—brigandines, sallets, swords, and mail as needed. We projected five to six hundred."


He lays out a document showing the production breakdown.


"More significant than the numbers is the quality. Steinmann has begun marking his blades with a distinctive stamp—a mountain peak, for the Basque iron that gives his steel its character. Aragonese knights have begun requesting 'Bilbao steel' by name. Two of King Alfonso's household guard now carry Steinmann blades."


"The workshop has trained twelve Castilian apprentices over four years. Three are now skilled enough to work independently on simpler pieces. Steinmann says another five years and we will have native Castilian armorsmiths capable of equipping an army without foreign assistance."


Diego frowns slightly. "There is one concern. Steinmann is fifty-seven years old and has begun complaining of stiffness in his hands. He works as hard as ever, but he has asked that we begin searching for a second master—not to replace him, but to ensure continuity. He recommends we look to Nuremberg."



Glass Workshop — Burgos (Secret)


Diego lowers his voice, though you are alone in the chamber.


"Alessandro Barbarigo remains in Burgos, and his secret remains intact. Venice has made inquiries—twice in the past two years, Venetian agents have visited Castilian ports asking questions about glassmakers. Both times, our people provided nothing. The workshop's location in Burgos, far from the sea, has proven wise."


"Production has grown steadily. This year Barbarigo expects revenue of two thousand florins—we projected fifteen hundred. His cristallo work is extraordinary. I have seen Venetian glass, Your Majesty. Barbarigo's equals it."


He produces a small glass goblet, perfectly clear, with a twisted stem that catches the light.


"He has trained four Castilian apprentices. Glassmaking requires longer training than other crafts—the heat, the timing, the breath control. Barbarigo says two of the four show real promise. In eight to ten years, Castile may have native masters of Venetian technique."


"There is... one matter." Diego hesitates. "Barbarigo has grown comfortable. Perhaps too comfortable. He has taken a Castilian mistress, a widow in Burgos. He speaks of her children as if they were his own. I mention this because it may affect his willingness to remain hidden. A man building a life may resent living in shadow."



Traditional Industries


"The infrastructure investments of 1434 have borne fruit across the realm," Diego continues, moving to a summary sheet.


"Leather in Córdoba: The goat herds have expanded as projected. Sumac plantations are maturing. Córdoban leather now commands premium prices in Barcelona and Valencia. Revenue to the crown through alcabala has increased by roughly three thousand florins annually above the 1434 baseline.


"Silk in Granada: The transition from raw thread export to finished cloth continues. Muslim weavers remain essential—they possess skills our Christian craftsmen cannot yet match. But we have successfully captured the value that previously went to Italian finishers. Revenue increase: approximately thirty-five hundred florins annually.


"Fishing in Seville: The fleet has grown from twelve to twenty-two vessels. Lease payments now total four hundred florins annually. More significantly, the increased fish supply has reduced prices in Seville's markets while increasing alcabala revenue. Total benefit to the crown: perhaps two thousand florins annually, though much of this is indirect."



Ceramics — Málaga


Diego's expression grows somber.


"And now, Your Majesty, the matter of Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar."


He sets down his papers.


"Ibrahim is alive. He is seventy-seven years old, and his hands shake when he is cold, but he is alive. He continues to produce his golden luster ware—perhaps forty pieces per year now, where once he made two hundred."


Diego pauses.


"Something has changed, though I cannot say precisely what. After your personal letter in 1435, he refused all contact for nearly a year. Then, in the winter of 1437, he sent a message to the Governor of Granada. A single line: 'I will speak with the King's man, if one is sent who understands beauty.'"


"I sent a young clerk named Tomás de Jerez—a man with some artistic training who studied briefly in Italy. Tomás spent three months in Málaga. Ibrahim would not teach him the technique, but he talked. He spoke of his craft, his philosophy, his despair at the conquest, his grudging respect for a king who would trouble himself with pottery."


Diego produces a small ceramic tile, perhaps four inches square. Its surface gleams with that impossible golden sheen that has made Málaga ware famous across the Mediterranean.


"Ibrahim gave this to Tomás when he departed. He said: 'Tell your king that beauty does not die with the man who makes it. It dies when no one remembers why it mattered.'"


"Tomás believes—and I tend to agree—that Ibrahim is testing us. He wants to know if we care about his art for its own sake, or merely for the revenue it generates. He has no heir, no apprentice, no family. His knowledge will die with him unless he chooses to share it."


Diego meets your eyes.


"This is not a problem that can be solved with florins, Your Majesty. It requires something else. What that something is, I cannot say."



Summary


Diego gathers his papers.


"In total, Your Majesty, our economic development programs are performing at approximately one hundred thirty percent of original projections. Revenue from crown-owned industries—paper mills primarily—now exceeds six thousand florins annually. Revenue increases from subsidized and traditional industries add perhaps another twelve thousand florins through alcabala and customs growth."


"We have trained over forty Castilian apprentices across all industries. Some will fail, some will prove merely adequate, but a core of fifteen to twenty show genuine skill. Within five to seven years, Castile will possess native expertise in papermaking, fine textiles, quality arms, and possibly glasswork."


"The programs are not merely meeting goals—they are exceeding them. If this pace continues, by 1445 Castile will be a net exporter of quality manufactured goods rather than a net importer."


He allows himself a rare moment of pride.


"What Your Majesty planted in 1434 is bearing fruit."



Diego stands, awaiting your response or further questions.

# Mediterranean trade in the 1430s-1440s: A commercial world in transition

The mid-15th century Mediterranean was an interconnected commercial ecosystem where grain from Sicily fed Italian cities, Aragonese saffron colored Florentine textiles, Portuguese salt preserved Northern European cod, and Genoese merchants controlled the flow of goods from the Black Sea to Flanders. This was a period of profound transition: Portugal's first tentative voyages down the African coast, Alfonso V's conquest reshaping southern Italian commerce, and Constantinople's final decades as a Byzantine capital. **The patterns established in these two decades would shape European trade for centuries.**

---

## Crown of Aragon: The Catalan commercial empire

Barcelona and Valencia served as hubs of a sophisticated trading network stretching from Flanders to Alexandria. By the 1430s-40s, this Crown of Aragon commercial system had evolved from mere redistribution into genuine manufacturing prowess, though the Black Death's demographic devastation still cast long shadows.

### Textile manufacturing drove Aragonese exports

The wool cloth industry represented the Crown's greatest commercial achievement. Production centers at Lleida, Perpinyà, Puigcerdà, and Barcelona produced **mid-quality woolens** that dominated Mediterranean markets. Valencia's protectionist measures—including a 1342 ban on foreign fabric imports—proved remarkably effective: by the 15th century, local production accounted for **over 90% of textile transactions** in Valencian tax records. Catalan cloth made up **75% of the value** of goods unloaded at Naples during peak trade years (1445-1469).

The quality ladder remained clear, however. English wool was the finest in medieval Europe, and Barcelona's manufacturers imported it to attempt high-quality production rivaling Flemish cloth. The Crown's textile strength lay in volume and mid-market positioning rather than luxury goods. Supporting industries flourished: kermes dye (scarlet) from southern Valencia, woad from Occitania, and alum for setting colors created an integrated production system.

**Saffron** emerged as another critical export. Grown primarily in inland Aragon's highlands, Aragonese saffron enjoyed exceptional reputation across Europe. Pyrenean customs records from 1445-1448 document substantial flows through the mountain passes at Canfranc and Benasque destined for Constantinople, Sicily, Genoa, and North Africa. The spice commanded high prices as both colorant and culinary ingredient.

### Salt and coral completed the export portfolio

The **Ibiza salt pans** generated enormous quantities of high-quality sea salt exported throughout the Mediterranean. Catalans carried Ibiza salt to Naples, the Maghreb, and Genoa, while the La Mata salt flats near Guardamar supplemented production. Salt's strategic value extended beyond seasoning—it preserved fish and meat, making it essential to food security across Europe.

**Sardinian coral**, fished and then crafted in Barcelona workshops, became an essential component of Catalan freight headed to the Levant. Eastern Mediterranean markets absorbed large quantities, while Barcelona developed specialized coral-working as a distinctive industry. Iron production, though less documented, supported a thriving weapons manufacturing sector—swords, daggers, crossbows, and armor ranked among Barcelona's "oldest and most reputed" exports.

### Agricultural production and chronic grain deficit

Valencia's irrigated *huerta* produced rice, dried fruits (figs, raisins, almonds), dates, and wine from Morvedre (Sagunto). These agricultural products rounded out cargo manifests alongside manufactured goods. Yet despite this abundance, **Catalonia experienced a serious grain deficit** from the 13th century onward. Sicily became the primary supplier, with Languedoc and North Africa providing supplementary sources. This structural dependence shaped trade relationships throughout the period.

### Italian networks and Mediterranean reach

The Catalan *Consolat del Mar* system, established in 1258, positioned consuls across the Mediterranean's major ports. By 1385, Catalan consulates operated throughout Sardinia, Sicily, Naples, North Africa (Tunis, Bugia), Alexandria, Damascus, Cyprus, and Constantinople. Relations with Genoa proved complex—intense commerce punctuated by wars (1331-1336, 1351-1360). In 1386 alone, 13 Catalan cargo ships arrived in Genoa; by 1392-93, the figure reached 33 arrivals and 36 departures.

The major cities reflected this commercial intensity. **Barcelona**, with approximately **25,000 inhabitants** by the late 15th century (down from 34,000 pre-Black Death), served as the administrative and cultural capital. **Valencia** had become the Crown's largest city, with **8,840 taxed households** by 1489, its unprecedented growth running counter to general demographic decline. **Palma de Mallorca** functioned as a crucial waystation—46.89% of documented journeys from 1448-1480 went to North Africa, making it the primary link to Maghrebi markets.

## Kingdom of Portugal: Atlantic horizons opening

The 1430s-40s represent Portugal's pivot point from a peripheral European kingdom trading Mediterranean commodities to the first European power establishing direct African trade routes. Traditional commerce with England and Flanders continued as the economic backbone, even as Henry the Navigator's expeditions opened extraordinary new possibilities.

### Salt and wine anchored traditional exports

Portuguese salt production centered on **Aveiro** (the primary medieval center) and the growing operations at **Setúbal** in the Sado estuary. By the 12th century, Portuguese salt had achieved international recognition for quality—the combination of abundant sunshine, coastal winds, and shallow tidal areas created ideal evaporation conditions. Salt flowed to Flanders, England, and the Hanseatic League, often exchanged directly for English cloth and codfish.

**Wine exports** benefited from the Treaty of Windsor (1386), which sealed the Anglo-Portuguese alliance and fostered commercial ties. By the second half of the 15th century, substantial Portuguese wine shipments reached England. Production regions included the Minho (vinho verde), Algarve, banks of the Tagus near Lisbon, and the Douro Valley, where flat-bottomed *barcos rabelos* transported wine to Porto. Madeira's first documented wine export to England came in 1456, inaugurating a trade that would flourish for centuries.

### The African trade revolution begins

Henry the Navigator's expeditions during the 1430s-40s transformed Portugal's commercial prospects:

- **1434**: Gil Eanes passed Cape Bojador, breaking a major psychological barrier
- **1441**: Antão Gonçalves brought the first African captives to Portugal
- **1443**: Arguin Island reached; Henry granted monopoly on navigation south of Cape Bojador
- **1444**: Senegal River and Cape Verde reached
- **1445**: First permanent trading post established on Arguin Island

The gold trade remained limited during this period—major flows would only develop with Elmina Castle's construction in 1482, eventually yielding an estimated **400 kg annually** by the 1490s. Initial African cargoes contained ivory, gum arabic, wax, malagueta pepper, and enslaved captives. By the 1440s, approximately **800 slaves arrived annually** in Portugal, beginning a trade that would reshape Atlantic history.

### Chronic grain dependence

Portugal faced structural grain deficits, having diversified agricultural land toward more profitable vineyards and olive groves. **Morocco** served as the primary wheat source, especially after the 1415 conquest of Ceuta provided direct access to caravan-borne grain. This dependence drove Portuguese expansion toward grain-producing regions and shaped diplomatic relationships throughout North Africa.

### Major urban centers

**Lisbon** housed approximately **35,000-40,000 inhabitants**, strategically positioned on the Tagus estuary eight miles from the Atlantic. Ships traveling between the Mediterranean and Northern Europe routinely stopped at Lisbon, making it one of Europe's best-informed centers for geographical knowledge. Genoese merchants had maintained a presence since 1317, while Florentine bankers provided capital for maritime ventures. The Jewish community (roughly 10% of population) proved influential in science, finance, and commerce.

**Porto** (estimated **10,000-15,000 inhabitants**) served as a shipbuilding center and wine export hub. Henry the Navigator launched the conquest of Ceuta from Porto in 1415, and the city's maritime traditions supported the Atlantic expansion.

## Kingdom of Naples: Grain, saffron, and political transition

The Kingdom of Naples experienced dramatic political change during this period. **Alfonso V "the Magnanimous" captured Naples on June 2, 1442**, ending Angevin rule and integrating the kingdom into the Crown of Aragon's Mediterranean commercial network. This transition brought institutional innovations while leaving fundamental trade patterns largely intact.

### Puglia wheat commanded Mediterranean markets

Apulian wheat ranked among **the most strategic commodities in Europe and the Mediterranean**. Francesco Balducci Pegolotti's *Pratica di Mercatura* documented an extensive international distribution network reaching Venice, Florence, Genoa, Barcelona, Constantinople, Alexandria, and even Bruges and London.

The Adriatic ports of **Manfredonia** (4,892 *carri* annually), **Barletta** (3,354 *carri*), and **Trani** (2,409 *carri*) handled enormous volumes. Export licenses (*tratte*) regulated the trade, with **79% of wheat** passing through the eight main ports destined for export outside the Kingdom. Florentine merchants—particularly the **Medici company, which controlled 33.4% of total wheat exports**—dominated the trade, investing approximately **25,000 florins annually** in grain operations.

### L'Aquila saffron and Calabrian silk

**L'Aquila saffron** (Zafferano dell'Aquila), introduced from Spain in the 13th century by Dominican friars, was considered among the finest in the world. Cultivated on the Navelli Plateau at 800 meters elevation, the saffron required **200,000-250,000 crocus flowers per kilogram** and **500 hours of manual labor**. A unique roasting process over smoldering logs distinguished it from competitors. L'Aquila's position on the *Via degli Abruzzi* (Florence-Naples route) combined saffron exports with wool processing from transhumance flocks.

**Calabrian silk production** centered on Catanzaro, potentially named for Byzantine *Katartarioi* ("silk spinners"). At peak periods, Calabrian silk reached **50% of entire Italian/European production**. The technology's value was recognized when Louis XI of France recruited Calabrian masters in 1470 to establish the French silk industry—Giovanni from Catanzaro introduced his loom (*métier de Jean le Calabrais*) to Tours.

### Olive oil and transhumance wool

Puglia's olive groves produced massive quantities of oil, primarily for illumination ("lampante" oil) rather than culinary use. Between the 15th-16th centuries, **8.7 million liters annually** flowed to Venice alone via specialized ships called *marciliane*.

Alfonso V institutionalized the ancient transhumance system in 1447 with the **Regia Dogana della Mena delle Pecore di Puglia**. Sheep traveled from Abruzzo mountains to the Tavoliere Plain via ancient grass paths (*tratturi*) up to **110 meters wide**. The Tratturo Magno stretched **244 kilometers** from L'Aquila to Foggia. Alfonso introduced Spanish Merino rams for crossbreeding, though Neapolitan wool never matched Spanish, Flemish, or English quality.

### Naples as urban center

**Naples was the largest city in Italy** during the Renaissance, reaching approximately 210,000 inhabitants by 1550, while no other kingdom city exceeded 20,000. Florentine, Venetian, and Genoese merchants maintained significant presences, with provincial economies tied to these foreign trade networks. The Medici structured their operations through the Trani consulate and extensive networks of Dalmatian/Ragusan shipowners—61 individual shipowners were identified working for Medici alone in 1486-1487.

## Kingdom of Sicily: Mediterranean breadbasket and sugar producer

Sicily under Aragonese rule functioned as an agricultural powerhouse, with grain exports dominating commerce. The island's volcanic soils and favorable climate made it one of the most prolific wheat producers in the Mediterranean, while sugar production reached its pre-Atlantic peak.

### Grain exports through the tratte system

Known as the "breadbasket of Rome" since antiquity, Sicily's durum wheat supplied Italian cities, Barcelona, and Eastern Mediterranean markets. The **tratte** licensing system regulated exports: merchants purchased licenses from the state, the *Maestro Portolano* administered the trade, and leading merchants obtained positions supporting crown revenue goals.

Over **50 ancient grain varieties** were cultivated, including Tumminia (short growing season, March-June) and the quick-growing Marzullo used during wartime. Grain flowed through **Palermo** (the central hub for negotiations), **Messina**, **Trapani**, **Agrigento**, and **Syracuse**. Genoese merchants dominated long-distance trade, setting up companies to purchase tratte and share profits.

### Sugar production at its Mediterranean peak

Sugar cane, introduced by Arab conquerors in the 9th-10th centuries, made Sicily **one of the most important sugar production centers** in the western Mediterranean by the early 15th century. Production concentrated in the Palermo hinterland, transformed into industrial territory with water-powered crushing mills and refining facilities.

**Pisan businessmen** provided crucial financing and trade infrastructure. Exports reached the Maghreb, Egypt, Flanders, England, Venice, and Barcelona. The French merchant **Jacques Coeur** was active in Sicilian sugar trade during the 1440s. Competition came from Cyprus (known for best quality), Crete, Rhodes, Morocco, and Valencia. However, **Madeira's first refining in 1432** signaled the beginning of Atlantic island competition that would eventually eclipse Mediterranean production.

### Trapani's industrial complex

**Trapani** emerged as a remarkable multi-industry center combining salt, coral, and tuna production. The salt pans, established by Phoenicians, operated continuously through the medieval period. Frederick II established a state monopoly promoting Mediterranean and European trade; by the Spanish era, Trapani became the largest Mediterranean salt port.

**Coral fishing** off San Vito Lo Capo and the Egadi Archipelago produced raw material for jewelry and religious objects. Late 14th-century documents show coral as **Trapani's largest export** alongside salt and tuna.

The **tonnare** (fixed-trap net systems for bluefin tuna) operated from Byzantine origins, perfected by Arabs around 1000 CE. Migrating tuna were caught from May-August, then preserved using Trapani salt—salted fillets, bottarga (cured roe), and ventresca (belly cuts) were shipped throughout the Mediterranean.

### Sicilian silk production

Silk craft, introduced by Arab conquerors and enhanced by Norman King Roger II's 1147 capture of Byzantine artisans, continued in Palermo, Messina, Catania, Agrigento, and Trapani during this period. However, the industry had declined from its Norman-era heights, and northern Italian production (Lucca, Venice, Florence) had achieved superiority. **Messina** would later process over **400,000 pounds of silk annually** by the early 17th century.

### Urban populations and character

**Palermo** housed approximately **22,000-30,000 inhabitants** in the 1430s-40s, having declined from 40-50,000 in the 13th century due to the Black Death and wars. The city functioned as royal seat, center of wheat trade negotiations, and home to diverse merchant communities (Genoese, Tuscans, Catalans). **Messina's** strategic position on the Straits made it the gateway between Tyrrhenian and Ionian seas, crucial for eastern Mediterranean trade.

## Constantinople and Byzantine trade: Final decades of an empire

By the 1430s, the Byzantine Empire had contracted to Constantinople itself, the Princes' Islands, and the Peloponnese. The population had collapsed from approximately **400,000 in the 12th century** to perhaps **40,000-70,000**—some scholars estimate as low as 25,000 by 1453. The 1430 Ottoman conquest of Thessaloniki stripped away a major commercial center. Constantinople remained strategically vital, controlling the Bosphorus, but economically it had become dependent on Italian merchant powers.

### Black Sea grain under Genoese control

The **Genoese dominated Black Sea grain trade** after the 1352 Byzantine-Genoese treaty granted unrestricted export rights. **Caffa** (modern Feodosia) served as the principal hub, with **Tana** (Don River terminus) and Danube ports (Kiliya, Licostomo) completing the network. Crimean wheat was highest quality, with the "bushel of Caffa" (281.51 kg) serving as the standard measure.

Trade volumes were substantial: in 1360, within 2.5 months, **10,200 bushels (2,522.5 tonnes)** of grain were exported from Kiliya alone. By 1384, Caffa supplied Genoa with 31,344 minas, representing **36% of total Genoese grain imports**. However, Ottoman pressure on the Bosphorus and Dardanelles made export increasingly difficult, while poor harvests in the 1450s left Crimean production insufficient for local needs.

### Alum: Essential for European textiles

**Phocaea**, granted to Genoese brothers in 1267, produced approximately **700 tonnes of refined alum annually** by the 1330s, generating profits of 50,000 Genoese lire. Alum was the **essential mordant** for textile dyeing—without it, Western European wool industries could not produce colorfast fabrics. Phocaea remained the dominant source until Ottoman conquest in 1455 and the 1462 discovery of Tolfa deposits in papal territories.

Annual exports reached approximately **665.7 tonnes** in the early 14th century, destined for Flanders, England, France, and Italian states. Processing required heating stones to 900°F for 18 hours, then weathering for four months—a Genoese-controlled technical monopoly.

Late Summer 1438 — Málaga



The journey south is long but uneventful. María proves an able chaperone, keeping the small party moving at a pace that doesn't exhaust the children while maintaining the dignity expected of a royal progress. They travel with a modest escort—enough guards to ensure safety, few enough to avoid the appearance of intimidation.


Catalina is serious throughout the journey. She keeps the ceramic piece wrapped in silk in her saddlebag, checking it each night before she sleeps. Lucia sketches everything—the changing landscape, the olive groves, the distant shimmer of the sea as they descend toward the coast.


Málaga still bears scars from the siege five years past. Catalina notices. She says nothing, but her eyes linger on a collapsed wall, a burned-out building not yet rebuilt.



Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar's workshop sits in the old Muslim quarter, down a narrow street that smells of clay and woodsmoke. When they arrive, a young servant—a distant relative, perhaps—regards them with barely concealed hostility.


"The master is working. He does not receive visitors."


María steps forward, but Catalina speaks first.


"Please tell him that Catalina has come. I carried something of his a long way, and I would like to return it to him."


The servant's eyes flicker to the silk-wrapped bundle in her arms. He disappears inside.


They wait in the street for nearly an hour. Lucia sketches the doorway, the patterns of tile visible through the entrance. María fans herself in the heat and does not complain.


Finally, the servant returns.


"He will see you. Briefly."



The workshop is smaller than Catalina expected. Shelves line every wall, crowded with pieces in various stages of completion. The smell is strange—iteite mineral,ite with something metallic beneath. In the far corner, near a cold kiln, an old man sits on a low stool.


Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar is thin, his hands gnarled with age, his beard white and unkempt. He does not rise when they enter. His eyes—dark, sharp, unforgiving—fix on Catalina.


"The king's daughter," he says. His Castilian is accented but clear. "He sends a child now. After the letters, the gifts, the pretty words about sorrow and beauty."


"He did not send me," Catalina says. Her voice is steady, though María notices her hands tightening on the silk bundle. "He asked if I would come. I said yes."


"And why did you say yes?"


Catalina unwraps the ceramic piece—the one Juan gave her, the one she carried all the way from Toledo. She holds it up, and the light from the doorway catches the golden luster, sending soft fire dancing across its surface.


"Because I wanted to know why this is beautiful," she says. "Not beautiful like a dress or a jewel. Beautiful like... like it matters."


Ibrahim says nothing. His expression does not change.


The silence stretches. María shifts uncomfortably. Lucia's hand, poised over her sketching paper, remains still.


Catalina takes a breath.


"My father said you sent him a message. That beauty doesn't die with the man who makes it. It dies when no one remembers why it mattered." She looks down at the piece in her hands. "I want to remember. Even if you won't tell me how you make it. I want to understand why you do."


Ibrahim's eyes move from Catalina's face to the ceramic in her hands. Something flickers there—not warmth, not forgiveness, but something.


"You carried that all the way from Toledo?"


"Yes."


"It could have broken."


"I was careful."


Another silence. Ibrahim's gaze shifts to Lucia, who has been standing motionless, her sketching charcoal hovering over paper.


"What is she doing?"


"Lucia draws," Catalina says. "She sees things. I thought... if you would let her, she could draw your workshop. Your pieces. So people could see them, even people who never come to Málaga."


Ibrahim stares at Lucia for a long moment. The girl meets his gaze, uncertain but not afraid.


"She has steady hands," he says finally. It is not a compliment, exactly. An observation.


He turns back to Catalina.


"I will not teach your father's people my secrets. I will not train Christian apprentices to make golden luster so Castile can grow rich from my family's art." His voice is hard, but beneath the hardness there is exhaustion. "My son is dead. My grandson is in Fez. When I die, this—" he gestures at the workshop around them "—dies with me. That is my choice."


Catalina nods slowly. "My father said it was your choice. He said we cannot force men to do anything. Only ask."


Something in Ibrahim's face shifts. Surprise, perhaps. Or simply the recognition of something unexpected.


"Your father said that?"


"Yes."


The old man is quiet for a long time. He looks at the ceramic piece in Catalina's hands—his own work, carried hundreds of miles by a child who wanted to understand why it mattered.


"Go," he says finally. His voice is gruff, dismissive. "I have work to do."


María begins to guide the children toward the door. But as they reach the threshold, Ibrahim speaks again.


"You may come again. If you wish."


Catalina turns. The old man is not looking at her. He has picked up a piece of unfired clay and is turning it over in his gnarled hands, examining it as though they were not there.


"I will," she says.


He does not respond.
